ratings.comment: Currently in 360. I do think Amanda wants students to do well but the layout of the course is confusing and unhelpful. It's never clear what should be turned in or printed out for class, expectations are unclear. I don't feel that her feedback is accurate to a true workplace. This is a required course otherwise I would not take it.

I had such a major problem with Amanda in GB360 that I had to appeal my grade to the associate dean, because her teaching and policies were so ridiculous. She word for word says that the class is too big for her to work with individual students. Not ideal.

I think all the negative reviews tell you the truth, that is genuinely how it is. Amanda has good intentions I think and seems to try very hard, but she would be a better fit in the English department or teaching a smaller non-required class. She tends to be very unhelpful and unkind when you meet with her 1 on 1 to solve a problem.

Amanda has three major problems: severe lack of real-world business experience, a massive stream of pointless, painstaking, long and not valuable assignments, and she can be very cold. Gen Bus 360 is easily the School of Business's worst class, and Amanda being uncaring for her students makes it much worse.

This class is a 3 credit class but the instructor's amount of reading assignments, group projects, quizzes, etc. is that of a 4-5 credit class. There is tons of busy work and convoluted instruction given. Do NOT take this course if you don't have to.

This woman just assigns an EXTREME amount of work. She is like your high school english teacher got lost and is now stuck teaching in grainger hall. She lacks empathy for students and should find another profession.

Way too much work for a three-credit course. Lectures are a waste of time. AK doesn't really do anything besides overexplain simple assignments, of which there are many. She clearly hasn't communicated in a business environment. If I sent my boss a six-paragraph email it would be immediately deleted. Sorry!

The class is easy but the amount of work is ridiculous.14 assignments last week alone. Grading can be subjective. Everything is done using a group setting. She does not teach, you read/watch a ton of lecture videos. Instructions are very overwhelming and unorganized. I do have an A, but the amount of time i have put into it isn't worth it honestly

Definitely would not recommend taking this person's class. The amount of work she assigns every week is absolutely insane. I do more for her class than any other class by a LOT. Overwhelming. Would drop this class if I could. Biggest mistake I have made.
Worst "professor" I've ever had. Doesn't know subject from a hole in the ground. Probably never even been in a "business," so why is she teaching me how to communicate in business?
Lots of busy work. Also not a very understanding individual. Grading procedures were not straightforward. Feedback given was not helpful and sparse.

Your grade is essentially determined by the final presentation and portfolio at the end of the term. Getting an A on these (and overall) requires a lot of work, but it is possible to skate by with an AB in the class - B at absolute minimum if you attend. Kenny is accommodating if you are diligent and work with her. Fairly dumb class but AK is fine.

Amanda really cares that you do well in the class.  The class itself is a lot of busy work, but make sure you choose a company and job you really like for the Investigative Report otherwise that will make it hard to do.  Overall she's a really kind professor who is arguably the most organized of the GB300 professors.
Go to class, act professional and get on her good side and you should be okay getting an A.
A lot of busy work. Really hard to get an A, but also no one gets below a B. Grading criteria isn't clear.
An awful instructor. Get on her bad side and you've got no chance for survival. She'll find a way to take it out on you. Thinks she's God Almighty.
Amanda is a good instructor and keeps class interesting. The class isn't bad, show up and put in some effort, you shouldn't have trouble getting an A.

Amanda is a nice, friendly professor. Quizzes are super easy if you read the book or have any common sense and exams are so easy they're a joke. The group project requires some work but she grades the final project pretty easily. If you attend lecture, it's very simple to get an A.

She teaches pretty easy material, but it is pretty tough to get an A.  However, she is very helpful if you go to see her in office hours, and she gives a ton of extra credit!  If you read before class and do the assignments, there is no reason you can't get an A.

Honestly, if you can, take this class with someone else. Amanda is teaching a pretty easy subject/class but for some reason she grades tougher than I would expect for this type of class. Lots of busy work. She's not an easy A but it's rare to get less than a B. And whoever said she gets hotter is dead wrong. I've seen more flame in an ice cube.

She is a good professor and never gives anything lower than a B but it is incredibly tough to get an A.  The projects are a lot of work but it's nice to get an easy A or AB (A in my case).  She gets hotter throughout the semester and has a subtle sense of humor.
No Comments
